passages.text: FCA investigating historical statements regarding biomass sourcing

We expect Drax shares to underperform today as this investigation has come as a surprise, at a time when an Ofgem investigation into a similar topic confirmed that Drax's biomass sourcing continues to meet government criteria. Our initial read of this investigation is that it is related to historical disclosures rather than an investigation into biomass sustainability itself - a similar topic to the 2023 Ofgem investigation. Our initial take is that this investigation should not impact Drax's existing subsidies nor the bridging mechanism, especially given the latter is being done for security of supply reasons, and we look forward to seeing more detail from the FCA as well as the government's response to this investigation.

The news: Drax was notified on 26 August 2025 that the Financial Conduct Authority ("FCA") has commenced an investigation into the Company covering the period January 2022 to March 2024 relating to certain historical statements regarding Drax's biomass sourcing and the compliance of Drax's 2021, 2022 and 2023 Annual Reports with the Listing Rules and Disclosure Guidance and Transparency Rules. The company will co- operate with the FCA as part of its investigation. The FCA has not given a timeline for the investigation.

Ofgem investigation recap: On 31 May 2023, Ofgem opened an investigation into whether Drax was in breach of annual profiling reporting requirements relating to the Renewables Obligations (ROC) scheme and other related matters. The investigation concluded that there was an absence of adequate data governance and controls in place that had contributed to Drax misreporting data in relation to its annual profiling submission to Ofgem for the compliance period 1 April 2021 to 31 March 2022. Drax accepted the findings of the investigation and agreed to pay £25m into Ofgem's Voluntary Redress Fund. Importantly, during this investigation, Ofgem did not find any evidence to suggest that Drax was incorrectly issued with subsidies. The investigation also did not find any evidence suggesting that Drax does not meet the government's threshold that a minimum of \(70\%\) of biomass must come from sustainable sources in order to receive scheme funding.

Bridging mechanism timeline: In January 2024, the previous government launched a consultation on supporting large- scale biomass generators when existing support ends in 2027. In February 2025, the government secured Head of Terms that will form the basis of a different agreement (known as the Bridging Mechanism) with Drax for support during the period 2027 to 2031. As a reminder, Drax is targeting average Adj. EBITDA from DPS of £100- 200m per annum during the agreement period April 2027 to March 2031, while we expect maintenance capex during the period to be around £70m p.a.
DRX.L, DRX LN Price (27 Aug 25):704p Price Target (Dec- 26):1,000p
FCA investigating historical statements regarding biomass sourcing 1
Drax (Overweight; Price Target: 1,000p)

We believe a clearly- defined strategy and a target to become carbon negative by 2030 put DRX on a path to a more sustainable, predictable and profitable future, as evidenced by the recent disposal of its gas generation fleet, and acquisition of Pinnacle Renewables. In particular, putting to rest the debate over DRX's strategic direction breathes new life into a company that has borne the brunt of UK decarbonisation policies in recent years, but now stands to benefit. Indeed, the UK government has acknowledged that biomass has the ability to deliver negative emissions, making it one of the "most valuable tools for reaching net zero emissions".

Our Dec- 26 1,000p price target for DRX is based on our DCF- based SoP valuation. The key assumptions underpinning our DCF are UK wholesale electricity, carbon costs, and biomass pellets costs. We conservatively attribute a 1.0x capital employed valuation for DRX's peaking generation assets and no value for UK or Global BECCS or the Cruachan II pumped storage project.
